content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice challenge! Should be good to go.
Pretty nice easy challenge! The only suggestion I have is to drop the first line in the output - it makes sense to specify length when reading data, but doesn't really add anything for outputs.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Unique and fun puzzle!

Goal
* Paragraph 2: Please add "in 24-hour" before "HHMM format" for clarity.

* Consider formatting "2303", "0332", "0", "2", "3", "0233", "2233" and "0203" as {{constants}}. This will let you remove the quotation marks while maintaining clarity and readability.

* Please add "." after these:
  • "These are anagrams"
  • "(different digit frequencies)"
  • the Wikipedia link

* Which time zones on the Wikipedia page are you referring to? For example, +00:30 doesn't appear in the main (middle) table, but it does show up in the bottom table as it was a historical time zone that's no longer in use.

Input
* Please delete the example. An example is shown in the Example section.

Output
* Please format both commas as {{constants}}.

Constraints
* Please remove the constraint. Since the input format is already specified as ±HHMM, the length is implied, and omitting it shouldn't cause any issues.

* Please add this as a constraint (if offset1 is the same as offset2, the answer will have to include all time points):
[[offset1]] ≠ [[offset2]]

* Are you planning to add cases where no anagram time pairs exist? If yes, that's perfectly fine and please proceed; if not, please add a constraint:
Each case is guaranteed to have at least one anagram time pair.

Tags
* Please change "time" to "Time".

Cases
* The time zones in some cases can't be found on the Wikipedia page.

Cover picture
* Consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.
Dear community, i am looking for hints to randomize the test-input. I'll be grateful for any hints.
Can you explain a bit more what you're trying to achieve?
Thanks for all the feedback. For offset list, I meant the table at the bottom - the link is now updated to point directly to this. All timezones used in tests can be found here.
Thanks for your feedback e2024. I updated the puzzle.

The Wikipedia time zone issue is cleared now that I know which table you're using. Below is the updated list of outstanding points:

Output
* Please change "hhmm" to "HHMM" for consistency with the Goal section.

Cases
* The current distribution is slightly unbalanced (considering only the +/- combinations in offset1 and offset2):

++: 2 tests, 3 validators
+-: 0 tests, 1 validator
-+: 2 tests, 1 validator
--: 1 test, 0 validators 

Please ensure that all four sign combinations are represented more evenly across both tests and validators.

Cover picture
* Consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.
Done. I'll let it sit for a week or so in case others have feedback and then remove WIP.

There are 400+ unique pairs of timezones with 1-120 results. I want to be able to use a random pair from this for validation to prevent hard-coded responses for the 10 or so pairs that I currently have in the tests.

Will Python's random function help you?

I also notice the current distribution is slightly unbalanced (considering only the +/- combinations in offset1 and offset2):

++: 2 tests, 3 validators
+-: 0 tests, 1 validator
-+: 2 tests, 1 validator
--: 1 test, 0 validators 

When you revise the cases, please ensure that all four sign combinations are represented more evenly across both tests and validators.
I am confused. Can I write code in the Input section of a test case/ validator ? How do I make the validator feed a random pair each time it is run ?

Ah I understand what you mean now. Unfortunately, the text-based puzzles in CodinGame don't allow randomised cases. Validators are always fixed cases. Random cases can only be achieved in contributions made using CodinGame SDK (those with the viewer enabled).
